title: Clarendon variant?
content:
This Clarendon variant is all over the place lately, but I can’t pin it down. Please excuse metro phone-cam type shot.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080705160443im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/indispensable_3643.jpg)

 [‹ Can't Identify Two Fonts: Please Help Me!](http://web.archive.org/web/20080705160443/http:/www.typophile.com/node/41891 "Go to previous forum topic") [Holy Asymmetrical A ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080705160443/http:/www.typophile.com/node/41870 "Go to next forum topic")
author: elzadra

comments.content: [Rosewood Fill](http://web.archive.org/web/20080705160443/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/rosewood/). It’s not just lately ... it has been rather popular for two or three years now.
Fashions vary depending where you live. Thanks.
Very true, Kate ... and you are certainly welcome.

One could argue about whether it’s fashion or rather availability, as Rosewood comes bundled with Adobe software.  
It really _is_ a nice typeface, charmingly uneven.

Kate, this kind of typeface is used very often like Mike said, even in Montreal where you took that picture. It appeared just after the “circus types” like Zebrawood and Rosewood Regular back in 2001-2002.

One of the reasons it’s uneven is that it’s meant to be the method for coloring the fill on [Rosewood](http://web.archive.org/web/20080705160443/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/monotype/rosewood_std_ot/). Fascinating how popular it’s become. I guess it shows that there’s a demand for imperfect wood stuff.

I feel like I’m meant to apologize for not noticing it earlier. My only excuse is that it’s now all over the metro with that accounting firm campaign, so it bubbled up through my subconscious on a few long trips on the Orange Line.
I always wanted a larger family of just the fill. Love that typeface!
